newsitem.title: UK: IBCA says may cut East Midlands ratings.
newsitem.headline: IBCA says may cut East Midlands ratings.

text.p: IBCA, the European credit rating agency, said it had placed the long-term AA and short-term A1 plus ratings of East Midlands Electricity Plc on RatingWatch with negative implications.
The move follows the announcement of an agreed takeover bid by Dominion Resources Inc, IBCA said in a statement.
Dominion is the parent group of regulated electricity utility operations based in Virginia, U.S., IBCA said.
"Dominion have indicated in the medium-term, the acquisition will be financed with a mixture of sterling debt (65 percent), including a bond issue, and equity (35 percent)," IBCA said.

Previous acquisitions in the British utility sector have typically seen between 50 to 75 percent of the acqusition price met with non-recourse funding to a speacial purpose British-based acquisition vehicle, where debt-servicing obligations effectively lie with the utility, IBCA said.
"In addition, existing ring-fencing regulations for acquired RECs would leave East Midlands financial profile vulnerable to structural subordination withing the larger Dominion group,"IBCA said.
IBCA said the outstanding 25-year 150 million stg bond, issued in 1991, contatins restrictions on dividend payouts in the event of a change in ownership.

"The maximum dividend that East Midlands may pay to a new owner is one third of the past three years' dividend payments (which total 885.6 million stg, including sizable special dividends)," IBCA said.
It said this will theoretically allow East Midlands to pay dividends that more than cover finance costs on the 1.3 billion stg acquisition funding.
"IBCA will be monitoring this aspect of the bid's development closely," it said.
IBCA noted that the deal faces regulatory hurdles in the U.S. and Britain.
